Award.AwardTitle: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2012
Award.AbstractNarration:
Flocking Behavior in Wild Birds: The Role of Seasons, Hormones, and the Brain

The roles of the hormones vasopressin and oxytocin in the regulation of social behavior have garnered considerable interest within the neuroscience community. These compounds modulate a variety of affiliative behaviors, including mother-offspring interactions and the formation of social bonds. Although the influence of oxytocin and vasopressin on social bonding has been firmly established, little is known about their relationship to social behaviors aside from bonding. Is group cohesion established solely through social bonding? In gregarious species characterized by the formation of large aggregations, maintenance of the group by close social bonds alone is unlikely. This research will investigate the relationship between hormones and variations in seasonal flocking behavior in the wild White-crowned Sparrow (Zonotrichia leucophrys), a conspicuous and abundant North American songbird.

Training objectives include learning: (1) to locate, capture, and handle wild birds and (2) how to integrate techniques employed in neuroscience and field biology. By examining the physiological processes underlying group formation within the environments experienced by free-living animals, this research stands to reveal a more comprehensive view of social behavior than currently exists. This research will also augment our understanding of winter sociality (group-living that is limited to the winter, non-breeding months) and facilitate comparisons of captive and free-living animals. Broader impacts of this award include: (1) research opportunities for undergraduates, (2) delivery of public lectures to local non-scientist groups, particularly those dedicated to persons with autoimmune disease; and (3) dissemination of research findings to those with learning and visual disabilities using audio files.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Neuropeptides—molecules in the brain that are structurally similar, but much smaller than, full-fledged proteins—are involved in regulating many behaviors and physiological processes that are critical to survival. Over twenty years of research have brought to light the involvement of nonapeptides, a class of neuropeptides that includes oxytocin and vasopressin (found in mammals, including humans), in a variety of social behaviors. Most of this ground-breaking work has focused on how nonapeptides influence social bonding, particularly between parents and offspring and between mates, but we have strong reasons to suspect that these compounds also contribute to the formation and cohesiveness of entire social groups—what we refer to as sociality. A related question is whether or not the nonapeptide systems are sensitive to changes in the physical environment (think ambient temperature, food availability, and day length). When you consider observations that animals of many different kinds form groups only at certain times of year, it becomes clear that we need to understand not only how nonapeptides influence sociality, but how this process helps individuals deal with shifts in their environments. I discuss these important questions in a review paper entitled, “Emerging frontiers in social neuroendocrinology and the study of nonapeptides,” published in the journal Ethology.

During my tenure as an NSF-funded postdoctoral fellow, my aim was to investigate how changes in the nonapeptide systems of wild animals reflect seasonal shifts in social grouping and the physical environment. I decided to use house sparrows for this research because they are easy to observe in the wild and found across the entire United States, a fact that allowed me to collect data from replicate—or multiple—sites that were environmentally diverse. So far, I have found that house sparrows gathered from sites in California, Washington, and Texas all show similar seasonal changes in flocking behavior, despite differences in their particular environments and the timing of reproductive shifts. In a forthcoming paper, I show that the layout of nonapeptide receptors (proteins that bind to and transmit the nonapeptide signal) in the house sparrow brain is similar to what has been described for other songbird species, a discovery that highlights the potentially widespread applicability of my findings. Current work will reveal additional details about these receptors, including how they change across seasons and with variations in the physical environment, and whether they differ between the sexes. My work on this project has provided undergraduate and graduate students with opportunities to learn both field and laboratory techniques, including autoradiography for receptors, enzyme immunoassays for measuring hormone levels, mist netting, data analysis, and several histological methods for examining neuroanatomy.
